linkTarget.anchoringText: Considering the above, it was decided to drill horizontal production wells in a row pattern. To make production cost-effective, boost productivity of wells and involve all reservoirs, horizontal wells need to be multi-fracked. (Figure 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Overall layout and design of wells drilled in the field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Overall layout and design of wells drilled in the field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Inflow to a multi-fracked horizontal is characterized by several filtration modes, going in succession (Figure 2), which differ by the type of flow symmetry: linear, the first transition (elliptical), an early radial, the second transition, pseudoradial. Under favorable conditions, the time interval in which manifested each mode is determined by the results of «log-log» diagnostics its characteristic angle asymptotes in a logarithmic derivative.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Log-log diagnostic characteristic filtering modes for MFHW.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log diagnostic characteristic filtering modes for MFHW.

linkTarget.anchoringText: That is to say, half-length, and by varying the amount of working cracks, we can get virtually identical to the behavior of the derivative of pressure with different combinations for a fixed distance between first and last crack (Figure 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Log-log plot of the behavior of the derivative of the pressure in the case of 3 (green curves, Xf = 42m) and 4 (brown curves, Xf = 30m) fractures at a fixed length of the wellbore.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log plot of the behavior of the derivative of the pressure in the case of 3 (green curves, Xf = 42m) and 4 (brown curves, Xf = 30m) fractures at a fixed length of the wellbore.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In general terms, it boils down to identifying the two radial modes of filtration during long-term monitoring of the hydrodynamic operation of the well. Just the number of working fractures is determined by the ratio of crack permeability mode is determined according to (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Determining the number of activeg cracks besed on position of the early and late pseudoradial flow regime.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Determining the number of activeg cracks besed on position of the early and late pseudoradial flow regime.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Several types of research made at one of the wells showed development of 7 fracking fractures [SPE 176710-RU], which confirms the conclusion obtained through the proprietary method, which said there to be 6-7 active fractures (Fig. 12-13). The paper SPE 176710-RU highlights importance of this novel experience for the in-country well servicing market.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Results of micro-seismic research in one of the wells [SPE 176710-RU].

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results of micro-seismic research in one of the wells [SPE 176710-RU].

linkTarget.anchoringText: Several types of research made at one of the wells showed development of 7 fracking fractures [SPE 176710-RU], which confirms the conclusion obtained through the proprietary method, which said there to be 6-7 active fractures (Fig. 12-13). The paper SPE 176710-RU highlights importance of this novel experience for the in-country well servicing market.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Results of a long-term hydrodynamic monitoring performed following the proprietary method. Blue horizontal lines show the early and the late positions of radial flow mode. Permeability data obtained are 10 mD and 1.6 mD, respectively (ratio ~6.3)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results of a long-term hydrodynamic monitoring performed following the proprietary method. Blue horizontal lines show the early and the late positions of radial flow mode. Permeability data obtained are 10 mD and 1.6 mD, respectively (ratio ~6.3)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The use of the mentioned information allows obtaining a convenient graphical tool for diagnosing possible unsuccessful fracking stages, qualitatively (Fig. 14).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: The format of a priori information submission when using the data on fracking fluid efficiency and the accured covariance maps. Black lines are conventional trajectories of wells. Green dots are locations of fracking stages. Red numbers are values of liquid efficiency for each stage. The background is taken from accrued covariance map. Color gradient from beige to green shows areas of anomalous values of this attribute, indicating a compaction.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The format of a priori information submission when using the data on fracking fluid efficiency and the accured covariance maps. Black lines are conventional trajectories of wells. Green dots are locations of fracking stages. Red numbers are values of liquid efficiency for each stage. The background is taken from accrued covariance map. Color gradient from beige to green shows areas of anomalous values of this attribute, indicating a compaction.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This method has been implemented at more than 40 wells, by now. It allows not only to substantiate start-up production rates of wells, but also to forecast their further operation even at an early operating stage, which allows to plan further field development with greater accuracy. This approach is trustworthy, as demonstrated by the high matching percentage of forecast and actual indicators (Fig. 15).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Superposing production rate of a well with 8 fractures (design) and a well with 4 fractures with actual production rate of one of the production wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Superposing production rate of a well with 8 fractures (design) and a well with 4 fractures with actual production rate of one of the production wells
